conclusion: A semi-cylindrical body has a rectangular surface and a curved (semi-circular) surface. Light enters through the rectangular surface and exits through the curved surface.

premise: For total internal reflection, the critical angle \( \theta_c \) is given by: \( \sin \theta_c = \frac{1}{n} \). Given \( n = 2 \).
The light exits through the curved surface from the angle \( 0^\circ \) to \( 30^\circ \) (since \( \theta_c = 30^\circ \)).
conclusion: The area \( S \) is the part of the semi-circular surface from \( 0^\circ \) to \( 30^\circ \).
The curved surface area of a full cylinder is \( 2\pi R L \). For a semi-cylinder, the curved surface area is half of that: \( \text{Full semi-cylinder area} = \pi R L \).

premise: The area of interest is a fraction of the semi-cylinder's curved surface, corresponding to the angle \( 30^\circ \) out of \( 180^\circ \): \( \text{Fraction of area} = \frac{30^\circ}{180^\circ} = \frac{1}{6} \).
conclusion: Multiply the full semi-cylinder area by the fraction: \( S = \pi R L \times \frac{1}{6} = \frac{\pi R L}{6} \).
